questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis?
A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statementsis false about this condition?

options.A: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
options.B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosis
options.D: Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.explanation: Vaginal itching is not seen in bacterial vaginosis. It is a symptom of Trichomonas vaginitis.About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic womenmostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, anddyspareunia.Option A: Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the absence of lactobacilli. This causes an increase inthe growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Myco-plasma hominis.Option B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. 3 out of 4 criteria are neededto make a positive diagnosis.Option D: Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or oral clindamycin 300 mg twicedaily for 7 days is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Treatment remains the same inpregnancy.

questions.question: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginaldischarge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginalmucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella.Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherentto the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, cluecells are visible.Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has anoffensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present.Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white.707Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.

questions.question: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not beseen?699
questions.explanation: An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is notan inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopicevaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a cleanbackground with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. Theseare called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced numberof Lactobacilli would also be seen.Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterialvaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence ofbacteria. These are called clue cells.Clue cells1Bacterial vaginosis

questions.question: Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What isthe most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.A swab of the vaginal discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. Themicroscopic evaluation of the smear is done on a gram stained smear. It would reveal a cleanbackground with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. Theseare called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organisms, and a reduced numberof Lactobacilli would also be seen.Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterialvaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence ofbacteria. These are called clue cells.708Clue cells Bacterial vaginosis

questions.question: A woman comes to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Onexamination, the discharge was profuse and had a fishy odour. Which of the following is thebest criteria to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis which is confirmed by using Amsel'scriteria.3 out of 4 of the following criteria are needed, to make a positive diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis:• A homogeneous, thin, greyish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.•A vaginal pH > 4.5.• A positive whiff test - an amine like fishy odour is produced when a drop of 10% KOH is addedto the sample of vaginal discharge.• The presence of >20% clue cells on saline wet mount. These are vaginal epithelial cellsstudded with adherent coccobacilli at the edge of the cell.Option A: Boer-Miesel's criteria is used for the prognostic evaluation of pelvic inflammatorydisease.Option B: Light's criteria is used for determining the nature of the pleural fluid i.e., transudate orexudate, in the diagnosis of pleural effusion.Option D: Nugent's criteria can also be used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. However, it is notthe best confirmatory method.

questions.question: In a patient with suspected bacterial vaginosis, Nugent's criteria is used to quantify thefollowing bacteria except....
questions.explanation: Nugent's criteria is used to evaluate three types of bacteria in a case of suspected bacterialvaginosis: Mobiluncus, Lactobacillus, and Gardnerella/Bacteroides. Bacteria are graded throughgram stain of vaginal samples.They are each graded on a scale of 1+ to 4+ where:709• 1+ is < 1 cell per field• 2+ is 1-5 cells per field• 3+ is 6-30 cells per field•4+ is >30 cells per field.Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4, but Mobiluncus isgraded only from 0-2. The total scores are then calculated and interpreted as follows:• 0-3 Normal-• 4-6 Intermediate bacterial count• 7-10 Bacterial vaginosis-

questions.question: A gynaecology resident noted a frothy, greenish, offensive-smelling vaginal discharge in ayoung lady. Whiff test was positive. Which organism is most likely implicated?
questions.explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely organism implicated in this patient, causing trichomonasvaginitis.The whiff test can be positive in both Trichomonas and Gardnerella infections. However, greenishfrothy discharge is seen in trichomonas vaginitis.

questions.question: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginaldischarge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had theappearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism.
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario, Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely causative agent.Vaginal itching and foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge are seen in trichomonas vaginitis.The given image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding oftrichomoniasis. This is due to microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.710

questions.question: Which of the following organisms can be detected on a hanging drop preparation?
questions.explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis can be detected on a hanging drop preparation. Trichomonas vaginalis is aprotozoan with four anterior flagellae, and a fifth posterior flagellum responsible for motility.The image given below shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman came with complaints of greenish vaginal discharge. On salinemicroscopy, motile flagellated organisms were seen. What is the best treatment option forher?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomonas vaginitis and the best treatment option forher is oral metronidazole 2 g stat.The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis is:••An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or• A single oral dose of metronidazole 2 gThe male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrentinfection. Treatment in pregnancy remains the same.

questions.question: A pregnant woman in her 7th week of gestation was diagnosed with trichomoniasis. Which ofthe following can be used to treat her condition?
questions.explanation: Trichomonas vaginitis is treated with oral metronidazole in pregnant women.According to the current guidelines, metronidazole is now considered safe for treatingtrichomonas vaginitis in pregnancy as it has no teratogenic effect.The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis in pregnant women include:711• An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or a single oral dose ofmetronidazole 2 g• Usage of trichofuran suppositories•Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal pH• Betadine gelThe male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrentinfection.

questions.question: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to your OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginaldischarge and intense itching. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moniliasis and Candida albicans is the likely causativeagent.The risk factors for moniliasis are:• Diabetes mellitus•Obesity•Multiple sexual partners• Immunosuppression• HIV•Pregnancy• Steroid therapy•Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy• Oral contraceptive pills• Poor personal hygiene.

questions.question: 702In an obese lady with complaints of vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH of 4.2 was detected.Which organism is implicated in this patient?
questions.explanation: The likely causative agent in the given clinical scenario is Candida which is known to flourish inan acidic environment. The pH of the vaginal discharge in candidal vaginitis is in the range of4-4.5.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing a candidal infection?
questions.explanation: Hypertension does not increase the risk of developing a candidal infection.The risk factors for developing candidal vaginitis (moniliasis) are:• Diabetes mellitus712•Obesity•Multiple sexual partners• Immunosuppression•HIV• Pregnancy• Steroid therapy•Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy••• Oral contraceptive pills• Poor personal hygiene.

questions.question: A 32-year old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching. Onexamination, you note a curdy white discharge and an inflamed vagina. What is the besttreatment for her?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of candidal vaginitis. A single dose of fluconazole 150mg is the best treatment for treating candidal vaginitis. Intravaginal antifungal(imidazole/miconazole/clotrimazole) vaginal pessaries or creams can also be used for 3-6 days.Curdy white dischargeCandida albicans

questions.question: Which of the following is not a primary site for gonococcal infection?
questions.explanation: Ectocervix and vagina are lined by squamous epithelium which is resistant to gonococcalinfection.The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitionalepithelium. Hence, gonococcus usually affects the following structures:• Endocervix• Urethra713• Skene's glands• Bartholin's glands.

questions.question: Which of the following presentations is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea?
questions.explanation: Haematuria is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea.Gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:•Excessive vaginal discharge associated with pruritus and inflammation• Acute unilateral pain and swelling over labia due to the involvement of Bartholin's gland• Intermenstrual bleedingNon-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:• Pharyngeal infection•• Dysuria• Rectal discomfort due to associated proctitis.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis.The causes of non-gonococcal urethritis are:•Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)•Ureaplasma urealyticum• AdenovirusHaemophillus vaginalis•Mycoplasma genitalium•Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)• Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.question: A 35-year-old sex worker was suspected to have chlamydial cervicitis. What is the mostsensitive method for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of chlamydial cervicitis is the polymerasechain reaction (PCR). It is fast, highly sensitive and specific (96%).

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman had complaints of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. Onmicroscopy, the following finding was present. What is the selective culture media used toisolate the causative organism?704

The gram stain of the cervical smear would showabundant leucocytes but no organisms.The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is currently done for the diagnosis oflymphogranuloma venereum.

questions.question: A patient with complaints of vaginal discharge was evaluated. On an endocervical biopsy,chlamydia was detected. How will you treat this patient?
questions.explanation: A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patientdiagnosed with a chlamydial infection.Treatment of chlamydial infection:• Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or)•Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)•Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 daysContact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the sameregimen.of

questions.question: A 25-year-old lady complains of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning.What is the route of administration of the first non-azole drug approved to treat thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestiveof vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatmentof vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral.Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucansynthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essentialcomponent of the fungal cell wall.The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindicationsinclude pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions arediarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting.715
